questions.text:
In which of the following conditions is the pulse in the given image seen?
  1. Aortic regurgitation
  2. Persistent ductus arteriosus
  3. Arteriovenous fistula 
  4. Aortic stenosis
  5. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
questions.solution:
The above image shows a water-hammer pulse (Corrigan’s pulse) which is seen in

  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Persistent ductus arteriosus
  • Arteriovenous fistula
  • Rupture of sinus of Valsalva

It is characterized by a rapid upstroke and a rapid downstroke. The rapid downstroke is due to the rapid run-off of blood into

  • the cavity of the left ventricle in AR
  • the pulmonary artery in PDA 
  • the veins in the case of AV fistula

 The rapid upstroke is due to increased stroke volume secondary to the hyperdynamic state.

Other options:

  • Aortic stenosis presents with pulsus parvus et tardus. It is seen as a low amplitude pulse that rises slowly and has a late peak.
  • HOCM presents with a bisferiens pulse. It is seen with a rapid upstroke to the first peak and a slower rise to the second peak.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man collapses during a family vacation. At the hospital, blood pressure is found to be 86/52 mm Hg, and random blood sugar is 49 mg/dl. His wife says that he has been on treatment for Addison's disease for two years but had forgotten to pack his medication for the trip. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of an adrenal crisis triggered by missed medication. In this patient who is a known case of adrenal insufficiency, IV hydrocortisone is the drug of choice.

However, in patients with newly diagnosed adrenal insufficiency, dexamethasone is used for the treatment of adrenal crisis. This is because dexamethasone is not measured in cortisol assays and would not interfere with the diagnostic tests, whereas hydrocortisone interferes with cortisol assays.

Acute adrenal insufficiency requires the immediate initiation of the following therapeutic strategies:

  • Rehydration - saline infusion at an initial rate of 1 L/h with continuous cardiac monitoring.
  • Glucocorticoid replacement - bolus injection of 100 mg hydrocortisone, followed by the maintenance dose of 100–200 mg over 24h.
  • Mineralocorticoid replacement - initiated once the daily hydrocortisone dose has been reduced to <50 mg as higher doses of hydrocortisone have sufficient mineralocorticoid action.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding transfusion-related acute lung injury?

choices.text: High titers of HLA antibodies are seen in donor plasma
Nulliparous women are the implicated donors
Patient presents with non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

questions.solution:
In cases of transfusion-related acute lung injury(TRALI), the implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. It may occur in any recipient.

TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind recipient WBCs. The WBCs aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. TRALI is one of the most common causes of transfusion-related fatalities. The recipient develops symptoms of hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray, either during or within 6 hours of transfusion. 

Recipient factors that are associated with increased risk of TRALI include

  • smoking
  • chronic alcohol use
  • shock, liver surgery
  • mechanical ventilation with >30 cmH2O pressure support.

Treatment is supportive and patients usually recover without sequelae.

questions.text: Resistant hypertension is defined as?

choices.text: BP >160/90 mmHg with three or more anti-hypertensives
BP >140/90 mmHg with three or more anti-hypertensives

questions.solution:
Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure being persistently >140/90 mmHg despite taking three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic.

Resistant hypertension is more common in patients aged >60 years than in younger patients.

Resistant hypertension may be related to pseudohypertension (high office blood pressure and lower home blood pressure measurements), nonadherence to therapy, and secondary causes of hypertension including obesity, excessive alcohol intake, and primary aldosteronism.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. Absolute eosinophil count >5000/μL. Chest  X-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with elevated absolute eosinophil count and miliary pattern in chest x-ray are suggestive of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a hyperresponsive pulmonary syndrome that occurs in response to trapped microfilariae within the lung parenchyma. It is a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.

Clinical features:

The patient has a history of residence in a filaria endemic area and usually presents with nocturnal paroxysmal wheeze and cough. Other manifestations include weight loss, low-grade fever, and lymphadenopathy. Hepatosplenomegaly may be seen due to the trapping of microfilariae in the reticuloendothelial system.

Investigations:

  • Eosinophilia > 3000/μL, leucocytosis
  • X-ray chest: Mottled opacities or military lesions in the middle and lower lung fields, increased bronchovascular markings
  • PFT: Restrictive changes in most cases and obstructive defects in half
  • Elevated levels of IgE and Antifilarial antibody titers
  • Microfilaria are sequestrated in the lungs and hence not found in blood

Treatment: Diethylcarbamazine(DEC) at a daily dosage of 4-6 mg/kg for 14 days.

 Differntial Diagnosis:

  • Bronchial asthma
  • Loffler syndrome
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis
  • Churg strauss syndrome
  • Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia
  • Hypereosinophilic syndromes

Other options:

Option A:  The classical symptoms of bronchial asthma are wheezing, dyspnea, and cough which is worse at night and keeps the patient awake in the early morning hours. Chest auscultation reveals rhonchi throughout the chest. The chest x-ray is usually normal but hyperinflation may be seen in severe patients.

Option B: Miliary TB occurs due to the hematogenous spread of tubercle bacilli. Clinical features are nonspecific and depend on the site of involvement. Common manifestations include fever, night sweats, anorexia, weakness, and weight loss. Blood investigations may reveal anemia with leukopenia, lymphopenia, neutrophilic leukocytosis, leukemoid reactions, and polycythemia. Chest x-ray shows a military reticulonodular pattern in some cases.

Option D: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis, also known as extrinsic allergic alveolitis, is an inflammatory response to various inhaled antigens. The clinical presentation can be acute, subacute, and chronic. History of exposure to the offending antigen is present. Chest x-ray findings are nonspecific and can show ground-glass opacities or ill-defined micronodular opacities.

Related Pearl: Causes of miliary shadow in Chest X-ray

Miliary shadow refers to innumerable, small (1-4 mm) pulmonary nodules scattered throughout the lungs. It is seen in - 

  • Miliary tuberculosis
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Pneumoconiosis – coal workers pneumoconiosis and silicosis
  • Healed varicella
  • Long-standing MS – can lead to pulmonary hemosiderosis
  • Alveolar microlithiasis
  • Papillary and medullary Ca thyroid

questions.text:
A 23-year-old patient presents with nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and malaise for the last week. He has a low-grade fever and developed jaundice yesterday. He does not have fecal incontinence. On abdominal examination, he has tenderness in the right upper quadrant. His laboratory evaluation is given below. What is the management for his condition?
IgM Anti-HAV positive
HBsAg negative
HBeAg negative
anti-HBs positive
serum aminotransferases elevated
questions.solution:
This patient with gastrointestinal symptoms and positive IgM- HAV is likely to have acute hepatitis A infection and requires supportive treatment. 

Since most patients recover spontaneously, only supportive treatment is required. 

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is an icosahedral, non enveloped virus that causes hepatitis A infection. HAV is transmitted by the fecal-oral route. Usually, it is due to contamination of food or water. It may transmit from person to person due to poor hygiene. It mostly is of mild nature, with only 0.1% of patients developing fulminant hepatitis.

It has an incubation period of 15 - 45 days. It may present with constitutional symptoms of nausea, vomiting, anorexia, malaise, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, and photophobia. 1-2 weeks after the constitutional symptoms, patients present with jaundice and tender hepatomegaly. Low-grade fever may also be present. 

This is followed by a recovery phase where the constitutional symptoms disappear but the hepatomegaly and elevated transaminases are still present. Full recovery is expected 1-2 months after the onset. 

Diagnosis of HAV is confirmed by IgM anti-HAV during acute illness. 

It can be prevented by HAV vaccination.

Other options:

Option B - Antivirals are not needed in HAV. They may be used in hepatitis B or C. 

Option C - Physical isolation is done in hepatitis A patients with fecal incontinence. This patient does not have fecal incontinence. Even then, HAV is excreted in feces in very small amounts. Using gloves to handle fecal matter is sufficient.

Option D - Interferon therapy is useful in the treatment of chronic HCV and HBV infections. They are cytokines that have antiviral, immunomodulatory, and antiproliferative activity.

questions.text: A surgical resident got his skin cut with a knife while he was operating on a patient diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. His anti-HBs levels were 45 mlU/ml. What will you do next?

choices.text: Give hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin and start hepatitis B vaccination

questions.solution:
In this scenario, since the anti-HBs antibodies titer in the resident is more than 10 mIU/ml, he would not need any further prophylaxis.

Post-exposure prophylaxis of Hepatitis B:

Scenario 1- The source is HBsAg negative

  • If the healthcare worker is not vaccinated- Initiate vaccination in the healthcare worker
  • If the healthcare worker is already vaccinated- No need for any action

Scenario 2- The source is HBsAg positive

  • If the healthcare worker is not vaccinated- Administer hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin (HBIG) single-dose and initiate vaccination. 
  • If the healthcare worker is vaccinated- Measure the anti-HBs antibody titers in him. If the levels are more than 10 mIU/ml, no further prophylaxis is required.
    • If the levels are less than 10mIU/mL, then administer HBIG single dose and reinitiate vaccination.
    • If the levels are less than 10mIU/mL, even after two complete series of vaccination- Give two doses of HBIG one month apart.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man working in the ship repair industry presents with a gradually progressive cough and difficulty in breathing. The flow-volume curve after spirometry in the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Pink line - Patient's response
Green dashed lines - Normal response
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 48-year-old patient working in a ship repair industry with a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve is asbestosis. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

The flow-volume curve of the above (patient 1) shows decreased total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right. This is seen in restrictive lung disease. Airflow is greater than normal at comparable lung volumes because the increased elastic recoil of the lungs holds the airways open.

Asthma, COPD, emphysema, and endobronchial neoplasm present with obstructive flow patterns. Although all airflow is diminished, expiratory prolongation predominates, and mean expiratory flow < mean inspiratory flow. The increased total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume will shift the flow volume loop to the left.

Vocal cord paralysis causes a variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction in which only the inspiratory curve would be flattened.

 

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung directly related to the intensity and duration of exposure. 

Asbestos fibers induce oxidative injury due to the generation of reactive oxygen species by the transition metals on the surface of the fibers as well as from cells engaged in phagocytosis. These mechanisms result in lung fibrosis.

Irregular or linear opacities initially in the lower lung fields are the hallmark of asbestosis in chest radiographs. A ground glass appearance in the lung fields may be seen.

The chest X-ray below shows bilateral calcified pleural plaques consistent with asbestos-related pleural disease:

 

No specific therapy is available for asbestosis. They are managed with supportive therapy. The most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure is lung cancer. Pleural and peritoneal mesothelioma are also associated with asbestos exposure. 

Other options:

Options A and B: Emphysema and asthma are obstructive lung disorders. In these conditions, the flow-volume loop would be a scooped-out curve.

Option D: Vocal cord paralysis causes variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction. The flow-volume loop would have a flat inspiratory curve.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents with dementia and gait difficulties along with episodes of urinary incontinence. Physical examination is notable for magnetic gait. There is no papilledema. An MRI brain demonstrates ventricular enlargement. After a serial lumbar puncture, his gait significantly improves. Which of the following is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The triad of dementia, ataxia, and urinary incontinence, along with the other clinical features and MRI showing enlarged ventricles, is highly suggestive of normal-pressure hydrocephalus. Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting is preferred in this condition.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a reversible cause of dementia. It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.

Clinical features of NPH triad:

  • ataxia (magnetic gait is described as slow and unsteady turns that are slow, broad-based, and short-stepped)
  • dementia
  • urinary incontinence

Papilloedema is not seen.

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting- It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options: 

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension presents with transient vision loss, headache, and papilledema. Medical therapy includes acetazolamide and furosemide. Topiramate is also used due to carbonic anhydrase inhibitor activity. Surgical therapy includes optic nerve sheath decompression (or optic nerve sheath fenestration) and CSF shunting procedures.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of recurrent headaches comes to the OPD with an acute episode of headache lasting for less than 30 minutes with redness and watering in one eye. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of an acute episode in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is most likely suffering from cluster headaches. Verapamil is not used for the treatment of acute episodes, but as the first-line preventive treatment for cluster headaches.

Cluster headache is a periodic headache characterized by daily attacks of short-duration unilateral headache lasting 8-10 weeks a year. It presents as severe, unilateral retro-orbital pain with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection. The pain, though severe, is characteristically brief (15-180 minutes). Patients are usually perfectly well in between episodes.

The most suitable treatment is pharmacologic prevention of future bouts of headaches. An acute episode can be treated with 

  • Sumatriptan 6 mg subcutaneous injection
  • 100% O2 at 10 -12 L/min for 15 - 20 mins
  • Sumatriptan (20 mg) and zolmitriptan (5 mg) nasal spray.
  • Noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation (nVNS) is also approved by the FDA for the treatment of acute episodes of cluster headaches.

The drugs used in the prophylaxis of cluster headaches are:

  • Verapamil - drug of choice
  • Prednisone
  • Lithium
  • Topiramate
  • Gabapentin
  • Melatonin
  • Greater occipital nerve injection with lidocaine and glucocorticoids

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presented to the emergency room with loss of consciousness, chest pain, and diaphoresis. On examination, she was grossly unstable and the bilateral pulses were unequal. ECG showed nonspecific ST-T changes. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and ECG showing nonspecific ST-T changes are highly suggestive of aortic dissection. As the patient is hemodynamically unstable the next best investigation is transesophageal ECHO.

Aortic dissection:

This occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta. It results in blood tracking into the aortic tissues and splitting of the medial layer of the aorta.

Predisposing factors:

  • Age
  • Hypertension
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Pregnancy
  • Other connective tissue disorders, for example, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Turner or Noonan syndromes
  • Aortic cannulation site (iatrogenic)

Clinical features:

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. It is associated with diaphoresis. Other symptoms are syncope, weakness, and dyspnea. On examination, there can be hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, findings of aortic regurgitation, pulmonary edema, or neurological manifestations. Unequal pulses or blood pressure in the extremities may be seen due to changes of flow in the true and false lumens. 

ECG findings: An ECG that shows no findings of acute myocardial infarction helps to differentiate aortic dissection from myocardial infarction.

Imaging: 

In hemodynamically stable patients the diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The characteristic diagnostic finding is a double lumen aorta.

Transesophageal ECHO(TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

Treatment:

The initial management is with beta-blockers to control hypertension, along with pain management. The preferred beta-blocker is esmolol. These reduce cardiac contractility and blood pressure.

Isolated use of a direct vasodilator such as hydralazine is contraindicated in acute dissection because these agents can increase hydraulic shear and worsen the dissection. CCBs like verapamil and diltiazem may be used intravenously if nitroprusside or beta-blockers cannot be employed.

Once hypertension is controlled, definitive surgical repair of aortic dissection is done. Treatment options depend on the classification.

  • Stanford Type A (DeBakey types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.
  • Stanford Type B (DeBakey type III) is best managed by antihypertensive drugs. Surgical intervention is indicated in complicated cases if the pain increases (signaling impending rupture) or when there is evidence of malperfusion of organs or neurological symptoms.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient presents with complaints of lethargy, increased thirst, and increased frequency of urination. On examination, his BMI was 19 kg/m2 and laboratory investigation showed low levels of C-peptide, raised blood glucose, and absent ketone bodies. Anti-GAD antibodies were positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Anti-GAD: Antibodies to glutamic acid decarboxylase
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 32-year-old, thin-built male, presenting with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy with laboratory investigation showing low C-peptide, and positive anti-GAD antibodies is suggestive of latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA). 

LADA is adult-onset diabetes with features of both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM). They phenotypically appear as type 2 but have autoantibodies like anti-GAD in favor of type 1. The general characteristics of LADA include:

  • Age of onset more than 30 years
  • Family history of autoimmunity
  • Low or normal body mass index
  • Low C-peptide levels
  • Anti-GAD antibodies positive
  • Do not present with ketoacidosis initially due to the slow progression of beta-cell destruction

The diagnosis can be made based on three criteria as given by The Immunology of Diabetes Society:

  • Adult age of onset (>30 years of age),
  • Positive circulating autoantibodies, and
  • No need for insulin treatment initially for several months after diagnosis

Initially, they don't require insulin but are more likely to be on insulin treatment within 5 years of onset. 

Other options:

Option A: Ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes patients are usually middle-aged men who are overweight and have a positive family history of diabetes. They have features similar to classic type 2 diabetes but often present with severe hyperglycemia and severe ketosis as in type 1 diabetes. Autoantibodies against beta-cells are negative in these patients. 

Option B: MODY or maturity-onset diabetes of the young is an autosomal dominant monogenic form of diabetes that occurs in patients less than 25 years of age. This is due to beta-cell dysfunction that impairs insulin secretion. The patients are non-ketotic and do not have pancreatic autoantibodies.

Option C: Type 1 diabetes mellitus most commonly develops before 20 years of age with most of them having evidence of islet-directed autoimmunity. Most of the patients present with hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis. There is increased lipolysis and ketone body production which results in muscle wasting, polyphagia, fatigue, and weakness.
In LADA, the destruction of islet cells proceeds at a much slower speed. This is why they present later, and may not require insulin treatment initially (unlike Type 1 DM).

questions.text: A middle-aged man, who smokes around 8-9 cigarettes per day for the past 15 years presented with chronic cough and breathlessness. Initially, breathlessness was mild, but now it has gradually affected his day-to-day activities. A pulmonary function test showed FEV1/FVC to be 0.65 and FEV1 is 75% of the predicted value. questions.solution:
In the above clinical vignette, the patient is a chronic smoker and has chronic progressive breathlessness, along with chronic cough. The diagnosis is likely to be chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. According to Gold's criteria, the severity of the disease in this patient is moderate.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the diagnosis of myocardial infarction?

choices.text: Chest pain on palpation is suggestive of myocardial infarction
Normal ECG at presentation excludes myocardial infarction
Normal baseline troponin and elevated 6-hour troponin suggests myocardial infarction

questions.solution:
A normal baseline troponin and elevated 6-hour troponin suggests myocardial infarction is the true statement.

Patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of myocardial infarction should undergo measurement of cardiac biomarkers. The preferred biomarker is cardiac troponin T (cTnT) or I (cTnI).

The admission troponin level may be normal if the patient presents early after the onset of symptoms. The troponin levels are assessed at the time of presentation, and 3-6 hrs after the onset of symptoms. If the 6-hour troponin level is normal then acute coronary syndrome is unlikely to explain the patient's chest pain. Patients with diabetes mellitus are more likely to present with painless STEMI.

An elevated troponin level is most likely suggestive of myocardial infarction and should be interpreted along with other investigations such as electrocardiographic changes and cardiac imaging to confirm the diagnosis. Levels of cTnI and cTnT may remain elevated for 7–10 days after STEMI.

Other options:

Option A: Chest pain reproducible on palpation is unlikely due to myocardial infarction. It is usually suggestive of a neuromuscular condition such as costochondritis, or trauma/strain.

Option B: A normal ECG at the time of presentation alone does not exclude myocardial infarction. In the case of normal ECG, other investigations including cardiac biomarkers and imaging are done.

Option D: The likelihood of myocardial infarction based on T-wave inversion is high, if ≥0.2 mV, and intermediate, if >0.1 mV.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to the OPD with a high-grade fever and a productive cough. Your senior asks you to calculate his modified CURB-65 score.  Which of the following is not included in the modified version of the CURB-65 criteria?

choices.text: Systolic BP ≤ 90 mmHg or Diastolic BP ≤ 60 mmHg

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient presented with symptoms of community-acquired pneumonia. Blood urea nitrogen is not included in the modified version of the CURB-65 criteria. This elimination removes the need for laboratory testing.

CURB-65 and the Pneumonia severity index (PSI) are tools used for decision-making with regard to whether or not a patient diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia requires hospital admission.

CURB-65 assesses five factors, which include confusion, blood urea nitrogen, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and age greater than 65. In a modified version of the CURB-65, the blood urea nitrogen has been removed. It also helps in assessing the mortality rate in those diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia.

The pneumonia severity index assesses for as many as 20 items under demographics, clinical history, physical examination, laboratory, and imaging findings. Based on the criteria the patients are stratified into five risk groups.

Related Pearl: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

questions.text: The sign given below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly). 

Marfan's syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

  • ectopia lentis
  • myopia
  • flat cornea
  • retinal detachments
  • early cataracts and glaucoma

Other systemic manifestations: 

  • thoracic scoliosis
  • spontaneous pneumothorax
  • striae atrophicae in the skin

Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist. Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist 

 

Diagnosis is based on criteria depending on the family history, aortic root X score, ectopia lentis, mitral valve prolapse, and presence of FBN1 mutation.

Other options:

Option B: Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, the wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

Option D: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum is characterized by abnormal deposition of calcium in the elastic fibers of skin, eyes, and vessels.

questions.text: A 57-year-old unresponsive male patient is brought to the hospital. He is pulseless and is not breathing. His lead II ECG rhythm strip is shown in the image below. What is the treatment for the given ECG abnormality?
questions.solution:
The ECG with no identifiable P wave, QRS complexes, and irregular rhythm is ventricular fibrillation (VF) and the treatment is defibrillation. 

Ventricular fibrillation is a disorganized ventricular rhythm. In a heart with ventricular fibrillation, there is little to no cardiac output as there is irregular cardiac contraction. In patients outside the hospital, sustained ventricular tachycardias are a common cause leading to ventricular fibrillation.

VF is a shockable rhythm. Thus, defibrillation must be performed in order to restore normal sinus rhythm according to advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) guidelines. In defibrillation, an electrical current is passed into the myocardium which 'resets' it by converting the dysrhythmia into a normal sinus rhythm. 

When the timing of electric current is adjusted according to the R waves or the QRS complex of the cardiac cycle, it is known as synchronized shock, which is administered in cardioversion. In ventricular fibrillation, because of irregular cardiac electrical activity, there are no R waves or QRS complexes to which the cardioversion can be synchronized. Hence, it is administered unsynchronized to the cardiac cycle.

 

Other options:

Option A - Magnesium sulfate is used to treat torsades de points. It is a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. 

Options C and D - Synchronised cardioversion and rate control are used to treat atrial fibrillation (AF). AF has normal QRS complexes with variable atrial activity resulting in irregular P waves of varying morphology.

A middle-aged woman presents with heat intolerance and fine tremors in both her hands for 6 months. She also complains of palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities. Examination revealed a BP of 136/86 mm Hg, tachycardia, and exophthalmos. Which of the statements is true in this patient?

RAIU - Radioactive Iodine Uptake

choices.text: RAIU at 24 hours is below normal

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient's symptoms point toward hyperthyroidism, and eye findings like exophthalmos are highly suggestive of Graves' disease. In this condition, the serum TSH is low, unbound T4 is high, and T3 is high. 

Graves disease: 

It is an autoimmune disease with a strong familial predisposition (50%) and females are at a higher risk with a peak incidence between the ages of 40-60 years. The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is due to stimulatory autoantibodies i.e Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) to TSH-R. Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) binds to and activates the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor resulting in diffuse toxic goiter and therefore, increased T4 and T3 levels. The clinical features include:

Symptoms:

  • Hyperactivity,  irritability, dysphoria
  • Heat intolerance and sweating
  • Palpitations
  • Fatigue and weakness
  • Weight loss with increased appetite
  • Diarrhea
  • Polyuria
  • Oligomenorrhea,  loss of libido

Signs:

  • Tachycardia, atrial fibrillation in the elderly
  • Tremor
  • Goiter
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Muscle weakness, proximal myopathy
  • Lid retraction or lag
  • Gynecomastia
  • Extra thyroidal conditions include ophthalmopathy, dermopathy (pretibial myxedema), thyroid acropachy, gynecomastia, and other manifestations.

Diagnosis:

  • Lab Investigations:
    • T4 and T3 increased due to the stimulating effect of TSI on the TSH receptors.
    • TSH is reduced as increased T4 levels in the blood lead to negative feedback on TRH in the hypothalamus.
    • Elevated TSH-R antibodies- diagnostic
    • Anti-Tg and anti-TPO are seen but nonspecific
  • Radiological investigations:
    • RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake) at 24 hours is characteristically above normal due to increased thyroid hormone production.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presented with an episode of sudden left-sided weakness and speech difficulty which resolved spontaneously within 24 hours. She has a history of recurrent miscarriages. ECG shows a sinus rhythm. Echocardiography revealed small vegetations on both sides of the mitral valve. What is the most probable diagnosis?

ECG - electrocardiogram
questions.solution:
The given presentation of neurological deficit resolving within 24 hours indicates a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The history of recurrent miscarriage points toward antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). These factors, along with the pattern of vegetations on the mitral valve, are strongly suggestive of Libman sack’s endocarditis.

Libman sack’s endocarditis is a type of non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE). It is associated with autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. The deposition of immune complexes leads to the formation of small (1 to 4 mm), sterile vegetations on heart valves. 

Vegetations can occur anywhere on the valve surface, on the chordae, or even on the atrial or ventricular endocardium. Histologically, there is intense valvulitis and fibrinoid necrosis of the valve substance. Patients may present with symptoms of stroke or TIA's due to emboli from the vegetation.

Other options:

Option A: Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart valves or the mural endocardium. The classic hallmarks of infective endocarditis are vegetations on heart valves. They are large, irregular masses on the valve cusps that can extend onto the chordae. Vegetations in infective endocarditis are friable, bulky, destructive lesions composed of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microbes. 

Option C: Marantic endocarditis or Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterized by the deposition of small (1 to 5 mm), sterile, non-destructive thrombi along the line of closure of the leaflets of the cardiac valves. A hypercoagulable state is a predisposing factor for marantic endocarditis.

Option D: Rheumatic heart disease is the inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves that typically results in fibrinoid necrosis within the cusps or tendinous cords. Vegetations in RHD are small (1-2 mm) along the lines of closures of the valve leaflets. Irregular subendocardial thickenings are termed MacCallum plaques.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with shortness of breath, cough, and fatigue for the last two months. He is a chronic smoker. On examination, blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, JVP is elevated and muffled heart sounds are heard. Chest x-ray reveals hilar enlargement and a perihilar mass and ECHO findings are shown below.  Which of the following additional findings are likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of pericardial effusion leading to cardiac tamponade. The features of Beck's triad (muffled heart sounds, hypotension, elevated JVP) and the echocardiography showing a swinging heart point towards the diagnosis. These patients show electrical alternans pattern on ECG.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output.

The physical examination findings in a patient with cardiac tamponade are:

  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Elevated JVP
  • Pulsus paradoxus: An inspiratory decline in systolic blood pressure by 10 mmHg. During inspiration, blood flows into the right ventricle. Because of the tamponade, the right ventricle is unable to accommodate the blood and this leads to bowing of the intraventricular septum towards the left ventricle. This, along with the underfilling of the left ventricle causes decreased stroke volume and blood pressure.
  • JVP will show a sharp 'x' descent and the absence of 'y' descent.

This patient is a chronic smoker, with a history of fatigue, cough, and a perihilar mass on chest x-ray likely has lung cancer. Malignancy is a common cause of large symptomatic pericardial effusions. The most common malignancy involving the pericardium is lung cancer. They may involve the pericardium by direct invasion or metastatic spread through the lymphatics or bloodstream. Chemotherapy and radiation may also cause effusions or worsen pre-existing effusions.

 

Pericardial effusion refers to the accumulation of excess fluid in the pericardial space. The accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space in quantities sufficient to cause significant obstruction to the filling of the ventricles results in cardiac tamponade.

Echocardiography is considered the primary imaging investigation for the evaluation of pericardial effusion.

  • The normal amount of pericardial fluid (15 to 35 mL), is not detectable on echocardiography.A quantity > 50mL is considered abnormal.
  • In the case of large effusions, the heart shows a characteristic ‘to-and-fro' motion on echocardiography, commonly known as the swinging heart sign. The appearance of a swinging heart is specific for pericardial effusion, and is responsible for the electrical alternans pattern on ECG, as shown below, which is an alternating QRS amplitude that is seen on any or all leads.

 

Other features that may be seen on echocardiography in patients with cardiac tamponade are:

  • Early diastolic collapse of the right ventricular free wall
  • Late diastolic collapse of the right atrium
  • Dilated inferior vena cava with minimal or absent collapse with inspiration
  • A greater than 60% relative inspiratory augmentation of blood flow across the tricuspid valve
  • A greater than 30% relative decrease in inspiratory flow across the mitral valve

 Other options:

Option A: Ejection systolic murmurs are characteristically heard in conditions involving the valves of the heart such as aortic stenosis or physiological high flow states like anemia. A pericardial friction rub may be heard in pericarditis.

Option C: Stratosphere sign is an ultrasound finding in pneumothorax that may be useful for bedside diagnosis.

Option D: Cardiac tamponade leads to a characteristic fall in BP on inspiration called pulsus paradoxus, not an increase in BP.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for 3 months but the disease is still progressing. What would you recommend for the further management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.solution:
Combination therapy of methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine (oral triple therapy) is indicated in the management of rheumatoid arthritis when the patient is not responding to initial treatment.

Joints commonly affected in rheumatoid arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrically involvement) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints

DMARDS, glucocorticoids, and biologicals are used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA):

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs): They are the mainstay of treatment. Methotrexate is the drug of choice in patients with RA. It can be used alone (in low disease activity) or with a 3-drug combination (in high disease activity) with other DMARDs such as hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide (reserve drug).

Glucocorticoids: Mainly given in active disease. May be administered in low to moderate doses to achieve rapid disease control before the onset of fully effective DMARD therapy, which often takes several weeks or even months. Second, 1-2 week bursts of glucocorticoids may be prescribed for the management of acute disease flares.

Biologicals: They are protein therapeutics designed mostly to target cytokines and cell-surface molecules. They are indicated when the disease is not responding to two or more DMARDs. They include:

  • Anti-TNF alpha agents: Infliximab, etanercept, adalimumab, golimumab, and certolizumab. Side effects include increased risk of infections, reactivation of latent TB, drug-induced SLE, malignancy, and hepatitis B flares.
  • Anakinra: IL-1 antagonist
  • Tocilizumab: IL-6 antagonist
  • Abatacept: Inhibits co-stimulation of T cells
  • Rituximab: Anti CD-20
  • Tofacitinib: JAK 3 inhibitor

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with fever, cough, dyspnea, arthralgia, and a painful rash on the lower limbs suggestive of erythema nodosum. A chest X-ray was taken and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, together with the presence of erythema nodosum, suggests the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology that is characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas.

In acute cases, patients may typically present with Lofgren’s syndrome, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum (as shown below), uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lethargy, and occasional fever. Patients may also present with insidious onset of cough, exertional breathlessness, and radiographic infiltrates.

 

Investigation findings in sarcoidosis are as follows:

  • Lymphopenia and deranged liver function tests 
  • Hypercalcemia (due to increased synthesis of calcitriol [1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D] by alveolar macrophages) and hypercalciuria (can lead to nephrocalcinosis)
  • Pulmonary function test - the most common abnormality is an isolated decrease in diffusion of carbon monoxide (DLCO). A restrictive pattern is seen in patients with more advanced pulmonary disease. Approximately 15-20% of patients have an obstructive pattern
  • Bronchoscopy shows a typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa. Bronchial and transbronchial biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. An increased CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio may be seen in bronchoalveolar lavage
  • Chest X-ray is useful for staging sarcoidosis
  • HRCT shows reticulonodular opacities that follow a perilymphatic distribution centered on broncho-vascular bundles and the subpleural areas

The presence of erythema nodosum with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray is sufficient to make the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. A tissue biopsy is not required in this case. A typical presentation with classical HRCT features may also indicate the diagnosis. In all other cases, the diagnosis should be confirmed by histological examination of the involved organ.

A chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy in sarcoidosis is shown below,

Management of sarcoidosis is as follows:

  • Asymptomatic patients- monitored for disease progression
  • Localized/ limited cutaneous and ocular lesions- treated using topical steroids
  • Multisystem involvement:
    • Systemic steroids
    • Other drugs like hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and infliximab are considered when the steroids are ineffective or not tolerated

Option C: The chest radiograph given below shows extensive bilateral reticulonodular infiltrates seen in miliary tuberculosis.

questions.text: The clinical finding in the given image is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a classical fish mouth (microstomia) appearance seen in systemic sclerosis/scleroderma.

Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features are seen in Scleroderma:

  • Severe pruritus
  • Initially, puffiness and non-pitting edema of fingers
  • The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly
  • Vasospasm and digital ulceration
  • Most patients have dysphagia and GERD
  • Mask-like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis 
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Other options:

Option B: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis. ANA, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith antibodies are positive in SLE. 

Option C: Angular stomatitis is the soreness at the angles of the mouth extending outwards in the folds of the facial skin.

Option D: Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is caused by coxsackievirus. It is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to you with complaints of dryness in the mouth and eyes. Serum reveals positivity for anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies. The test shown in the image below was positive with a score of < 5 mm in 5 minutes without anesthesia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The test shown above is Schirmer's test and the likely diagnosis is Sjögren's syndrome. 

Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that involves lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. This manifests as xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes). It is associated with autoantibodies anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B.

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca can be diagnosed by Schirmer's test. This test measures the quantity of tears produced. Two marked strips of paper are placed between the globe and the lower eyelid and the patient is instructed to close their eyes for 5 minutes. The tears produced spread along the paper by capillary action. The distance is measured. A score of more than 10 mm is considered to be normal while that of less than 5 mm is considered deficient. 

A number of other systems can be involved as well. For example, atrophic gastritis, esophageal mucosal atrophy, and vaginal dryness. Extraglandular or systemic manifestations can also be present. These manifest as fatigue, arthritis, Raynaud's phenomenon, and myalgia. 

Diagnosis of primary Sjögren's syndrome requires the following: 

  • Eye and/or mouth dryness
  • Eye tests disclose keratoconjunctivitis sicca
  • Mouth evaluation reveals dry oral mucosa and/or
  • Presence of anti-Ro or anti-La autoantibodies

A labial biopsy is a must to confirm the diagnosis and determine the prognosis. 

Treatment of Sjögren's syndrome is directed at treating the symptoms and complications. Artificial tears can be used for dry eyes and propionic acid gel for vaginal dryness. Pilocarpine can help increase oral secretions and hydroxychloroquine can be used to treat arthritis. 

Other options: 

Option A - Scleroderma is associated with xerostomia. However, it is more classically represented by skin thickening, telangiectasia, and lung and renal involvement. In addition, it has anti-topoisomerase and anti-centromere antibodies. 

Option B - Dehydration can present with dry mouth. However, anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are not involved. 

Option C - Sarcoidosis is a multisystemic inflammatory disease characterized by noncaseating granulomas. Ocular manifestations of sarcoidosis include anterior uveitis, retinitis, and pars planitis. Patients would have increased tearing. 

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: All of the following favour a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Painless diarrhoea or constipation does not favour the diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterised by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. Since there is no specific diagnostic marker for IBS, the diagnosis is based on Rome IV criteria, which include the clinical manifestations of the disease. Abdominal pain is an anchor feature of IBS. It should be associated (improvement or worsening) with defecation or with a change in the frequency or form of stool. Painless diarrhoea or constipation does not fulfil the criteria to be diagnosed as IBS. The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of IBS.

The extent of the diagnostic evaluation of a patient suspected to have IBS depends on the possibility of an organic disorder in that patient. A complete blood count and a sigmoidoscopy should be done for most patients. In addition, stool samples should be examined for ova and parasites in patients who have diarrhoea-predominant IBS. The mainstay of treatment for IBS is a diet low in fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols (FODMAPs). Pharmacotherapy consists of Alosetron (5-HT3 antagonist) or Loperamide for diarrhoea-predominant IBS and psyllium husk, lactulose, Lubiprostone, and Prucalopride (5-HT4 agonist) for constipation-predominant IBS. Peppermint oil is effective in improving abdominal pain associated with IBS, but probiotics have shown no benefit.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic alcoholic presents to you with distention of the abdomen, behavioural changes, yellowish discoloration of the skin, and decreased urine output. His laboratory investigations show elevated liver enzymes and creatinine. If kidneys appear normal on ultrasonography, what is the definitive treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point to a diagnosis of hepatorenal syndrome and the definitve treatment of the same is liver transplantation. 
 
Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) is a form of functional renal failure without any renal pathology that occurs in some patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure. The pathophysiological hallmark is severe renal vasoconstriction.
 
There are two types of HRS:
  • Type 1 HRS: There is progressive impairment in renal function and a marked decline in creatinine clearance within 1–2 weeks of presentation.
  • Type 2 HRS: There is a drop in glomerular filtration rate with elevated creatinine levels. It has a better prognosis than type 1 HRS.

Ultrasound of the kidney shows normal study and hyaline casts may be observed, indicating prerenal failure.

Management:

  • Stop diuretics
  • Albumin infusion at 1g/kg/day
  • Medical management:
    • Vasopressin analogs- terlipressin
    • Somatostatin analogs- octreotide
    • Alpha-adrenergic agonists- midodrine, noradrenaline
  • Definitive treatment: Liver transplantation

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with features of parkinsonism and cerebellar features. An MRI brain was done and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given MRI characteristically shows the pontine hot cross bun sign which is highly suggestive of multiple system atrophy.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a type of atypical Parkinson's disease. Along with the features of Parkinson's disease, they also have cerebellar and autonomic features. The common autonomic feature seen in these patients is orthostatic hypotension. MSA is characterized by the presence of degeneration in the striatum, cerebellum, and inferior olivary nuclei coupled with characteristic glial cytoplasmic inclusions. These inclusions stain positively for α-synuclein.

It is further divided into :

  • MSA-P: predominantly parkinsonian features
  • MSA-C: predominantly cerebellar features

Characteristic MRI findings include:

  • MSA-P: T2 weighted imaging demonstrates hypointensity due to iron deposition
  • MSA-C: cerebellar and brainstem atrophy causing pontine hot cross bun sign

Other options:

Option A: Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition caused by certain drugs having D2 antagonistic action (typical antipsychotics). The decrease in dopaminergic activity results in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Anticholinergics act by restoring balance. 

Option C: Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a form of atypical parkinsonism that is characterized by slow ocular saccades, eyelid apraxia, and restricted vertical eye movements with downward gaze palsy. Patients also have hyperextension of the neck with gait disturbances and frequent falls. MRI may reveal characteristic atrophy of the midbrain with normal pons. This is called a hummingbird sign. There is degeneration of the striatum, subthalamic nucleus, midline thalamic nuclei, and pallidum, coupled with neurofibrillary tangles and inclusions that stain for tau protein.

Option D: Dementia pugilistica/punch drunk syndrome is post-traumatic dementia, not degenerative dementia. This occurs in boxers & football players after repeated head trauma over many years. It is characterized by emotional lability, dysarthria, and impulsivity.

questions.text: You are on duty in the gastroenterology department as a second-year resident, evaluating patients for upper and lower gastrointestinal lesions. What will be your diagnosis of the following images?

choices.text: A- Barrett's esophagus, B- Mallory Weiss tear
A- Mallory Weiss tear, B- Barrett's esophagus
A- Crohn’s Disease, B- Ulcerative Colitis
A- Ulcerative Colitis, B- Crohn’s Disease

questions.solution:
Image A shows ulcerative colitis and image B shows Crohn's disease.

The given image A shows continuous involvement of mucosa with no normal mucosa in between, which indicates ulcerative colitis. 

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

Colonoscopy shows loss of typical vascular pattern, granularity, friability, and ulceration involving the distal rectum, extending proximally in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns. Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. 

Image B shows a cobblestone appearance seen in Crohn's disease. Normal mucosa in between the ulcers leads to this appearance. Fine granular mucosa is the earliest barium enema finding in Ulcerative colitis. Fistula is seen with Crohn’s disease.

Crohn's disease may occur in any area of the GI tract, but the most common sites involved at presentation are the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum. It is associated with smoking.

 In Crohn's disease, the following are seen:

  • Aphthous ulcers - Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas

Other options:

Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the mucosal lining of the swallowing tube that connects the mouth to the stomach (esophagus) becomes damaged by acid reflux, which causes the lining to thicken and become red. It is associated with an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

 

Mallory Weiss tear is due to a longitudinal tear in mucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction. It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or staining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital with complaints of blood-stained sputum. He has smoked around 1.5 packs per day for the last 20 years. Bronchoscopy was suggestive of lung carcinoma. A biopsy was obtained and is shown below. The cells were positive for thyroid transcription factor-1, napsin A and were negative for p63 and p40. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of adenocarcinoma lung. The microscopic image of the tissue shows an increased mucinous type of cells and their characteristics growth along the pre-existing alveolar septa.

Smoking is a major risk factor for developing lung cancer. Other risk factors that can contribute are industrial chemical exposure, air pollution, etc.

They are broadly divided into

  1. Small cell lung cancer
  2. Non-small cell lung cancer
    1. Adenocarcinoma
    2. Squamous cell carcinoma
    3. Large cell carcinoma

Though adenocarcinoma is the most common tumor of the lung in non-smokers, it can be seen in smokers as well. It is also more common in women. Adenocarcinoma of the lung occurs in the periphery of the lung, frequently in areas of chronic scarring caused by chronic inflammatory changes. 

Clinical features include cough, chest pain, hemoptysis, and symptoms due to metastasis. Some lung cancers are responsible for paraneoplastic syndromes.

Lung adenocarcinomas are now classified by their predominant pattern:

  • Lepidic pattern (At the periphery of the tumor, the tumor cells crawl along the surrounding normal alveoli)
  • Acinar pattern
  • Papillary pattern
  • Solid patterns (poor prognosis)

Lung nodules should always be compared with previous films. CT scan is done for further evaluation and biopsy is done to confirm the diagnosis.

In the image below glandular differentiation can be noted which is seen in adenocarcinoma of the lung.

Other options:

Option B: Small cell carcinomas:

They have the strongest association with smoking. They include loss-of-function mutations involving TP53, RB, and chromosome 3p deletions. Small cell carcinomas arise in the bronchi or in the periphery of the lungs. Extensive necrosis leads to the coating of the surrounding walls by DNA. This appears as basophilic staining of the vascular walls and is called the Azzopardi effect. They express chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56.

Below image- Small cell carcinoma:

Option D: Large cell carcinoma 

It is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial tumor that lacks the cytologic features of other forms of lung cancer. They do not express markers of adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma.

Option A: Squamous cell carcinomas

They are commonly found in men and are strongly associated with smoking. They are located in the central or perihilar region. It can grow as an exophytic mass in the bronchial lumen leading to bronchial obstruction. They are positive for p63 and p40.

questions.text:
A patient with asthma is being evaluated. His FEV1 values were measured before and after the administration of a short-acting beta-agonist. Which of the following values represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in this condition?

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in the first minute

FVC - Forced vital capacity

choices.text: > 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1
> 50% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 500 mL increase in FEV1
> 20% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 410 mL increase in FEV1
> 6% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 100 mL increase in FEV1

questions.solution:
Reversibility of obstruction in asthma has to be demonstrated by a minimum of 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1 in response to inhalation of short-acting beta-agonist (SABA).

In asthma, there is reversible bronchoconstriction leading to wheezing, breathlessness, and cough. Thus, on administering a SABA, there is bronchial relaxation and relief of symptoms. 

Asthma is generally diagnosed clinically based on symptoms alone. However, there are a number of other conditions that can be misdiagnosed as asthma such as causes of wheeze (bronchogenic carcinoma, foreign body aspiration), cough (gastroesophageal reflux, chronic bronchitis, rhinitis), and dyspnea (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pulmonary edema, or obesity). Misdiagnosis would lead to a delay in management. Thus, it is ideal that the clinical diagnosis of asthma is confirmed by pulmonary function tests. 

  • Spirometry: It is a non-invasive investigation that can be used to approximate lung volumes. This shows an obstructive pattern
    • Decreased FEV1
    • Decreased or normal FVC
    • Decreased FEV1/FVC
  • Bronchodilator reversibility: Spirometry is performed both before and after inhalation of a short-acting bronchodilator (400 mcg of β2 agonist or 160 mcg of anticholinergic). A 12% and 200 mL increase in FEV1 compared to pre-bronchodilator value is diagnostic of asthma in adults. 
  • Bronchial provocation test: Provocative stimulus (histamine, methacholine, inhaled mannitol, exercise, eucapnic hyperventilation with dry or cold air) is used to test the presence of airway hyperresponsiveness.  A fall of ≥20% in FEV1 from baseline, with a standard dose of methacholine (methacholine challenge test), is diagnostic of asthma.
  • Peak expiratory flow (PEF): PEF readings are taken twice daily for over 2 weeks. The average daily diurnal PEF variability of >10% is diagnostic of asthma in adults.

A 66-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fatiguability and chronic back pain. On evaluation, he was found to have anemia and hypercalcemia. The X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following is not seen in this patient?
  1. Plasma cells in 24-hr urine analysis
  2. Elevated Alkaline phosphatase
  3. Normocytic normochromic anemia 
  4. Osteolytic bone lesions
  5. Elevated ESR
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 2 are incorrect/ not seen in this patient.

The given X-ray of the skull demonstrating the typical “punched out” lesions in an elderly male with chronic back pain, fatigue, anemia, and hypercalcemia are highly suggestive of multiple myeloma. It is characterized by normal serum alkaline phosphatase (due to the absence of osteoblastic activity), and plasma cells in bone marrow (not in urine).

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with an increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia, elevated ESR, hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: M spikes
  • Urinalysis: Bence Jones proteinuria

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presents with electric shock-like sensations that go down her legs for the last two days. A few months ago, she had bilaterally decreased visual acuity which spontaneously resolved. Her T2-weighted MRI is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is multiple sclerosis (MS). 

The MRI given depicts Dawson's fingers which are areas of perivenous demyelination that are seen as lesions that are perpendicular to the ventricle. They appear as hyperintense areas on the T2-weighted images.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation, multiple demyelinating plaques, and relapsing and remitting symptoms. It occurs due to infiltration of the white matter by T cells and macrophages leading to axonal damage and neurodegeneration. It presents abruptly or insidiously with variable intensity of symptoms depending on the location. 

The most common symptoms experienced are as follows:

  1. Sensory symptoms:
    1. Paresthesia, pins and needles sensations, hypoesthesia
    2. Horizontal cut-off on limbs for sensory involvement suggests lesions at the level of the spinal cord 
    3. Pain
  2. Optic neuritis:
    1. Reduced visual acuity, color perception, dimness in the central visual field, unilaterally or bilaterally.
    2. Periorbital pain
    3. Funduscopy: optic disc swelling, pallor
  3. Weakness of limbs
    1. Loss of strength, speed, dexterity
    2. Gait disturbance
    3. Upper motor neuron weakness
    4. Pyramidal signs: spasticity, hyperreflexia
  4. Facial weakness 
  5. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia - bilaterally

Paroxysmal symptoms may occur, characterized by short duration and high-frequency occurrence per day. These can manifest as Lhermitte's sign (electric shock-like sensations that go down legs or back on neck flexion), and Uthoff symptom (neurological symptoms produced by elevated core body temperature). Other symptoms may include dysarthria, trigeminal neuralgia, bladder dysfunction, and fatigue.

MS can have three different clinical courses: 

  1. Relapsing or bout onset (90%) of cases. Here, there is complete recovery between episodes. As the disease progresses, the recovery may not be complete. 
  2. Secondary progressive MS starts as relapsing MS but then experiences decreased function as a result of the attacks.
  3. Primary progressive MS (10% of the cases) has a consistent decline in function from disease onset. They do not have discrete episodes. 

Other options: 

Option A: Thalamic stroke is usually unilateral and is characterized by hemi-sensory disturbance throughout the body. 

Option C: Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by extreme episodic pain affecting the area of the face supplied by the trigeminal nerve except for the ophthalmic division. It is of sudden onset and short duration, lasting up to a few minutes. 

Option D: Neuromyelitis optical (NMO) is characterized by recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis. It is similar in presentation to MS except that NMO is severe, bilateral, and can cause severe visual loss. Myelitis usually involves three or more contiguous vertebral segments. NMO does not have progressive symptoms in contrast to MS.

questions.text: The parents of a 9-year-old girl have often noticed her staring blankly for a few minutes, which is sometimes associated with chewing movements. There were also complaints of daydreaming and a decline in school performance. During the episodes, she does not have a problem with maintaining her posture. The EEG of the child is given below. Which of the following is a first-line agent to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and EEG showing a generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern, is diagnostic of absence seizures. Of the given antiepileptic drugs, sodium valproate is the first-line agent to treat this condition.

Typical absence seizures are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without loss of postural control. There is no postictal confusion. The following subtle motor signs may accompany the episodes:

  • Rapid blinking of the eyelids
  • Chewing movements
  • Small-amplitude clonic movements of the hands

Hyperventilation has a tendency to provoke absence seizures.

Ethosuximide and valproic acid are the only 2 FDA-approved first-line antiepileptic drugs for the absence seizures. However, between these 2 drugs, ethosuximide would be a better first-line treatment choice for uncomplicated typical absence seizures.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman admitted to the surgical ward had been diagnosed with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Which of the following is not a suitable next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Switching to warfarin is not a suitable next step for patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). 

Warfarin should not be administered in HIT until platelets return to their baseline level. If warfarin was administered, give vitamin K to restore the INR to normal. 

Patients with HIT, particularly those with associated thrombosis, have increased thrombin generation that can lead to consumption of protein C. If these patients are given warfarin without a concomitant parenteral anticoagulant to inhibit thrombin or thrombin generation, the further decrease in protein C levels induced by the vitamin K antagonist can trigger skin necrosis.

HIT is a life-threatening complication of exposure to heparin. It occurs more with unfractionated heparin than with low molecular weight (LMW) heparin. It is more common in surgical patients and more common in women than in men.

HIT results from an autoantibody directed against endogenous platelet factor 4 (PF4) in complex with heparin. These antibodies bind simultaneously to the heparin-PF4 complex and to platelet Fc receptors, activating the platelets and generating platelet microparticles. This can cause catastrophic arterial and venous thrombosis.

Features:

  • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count of ≤100,000/μL or a decrease in platelet count of ≥50%
  • Platelet count falls 5–10 days after starting heparin.
  • Venous thrombosis more common than arterial thrombosis

Investigations:

  1. ELISA to detect antibodies against heparin-PF4 complexes (most sensitive)
  2. Platelet activation assays
  3. Serotonin release assay (most specific)

Treatment:

  1. Stop all heparin.
  2. Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux or rivaroxaban.
  3. Do not give platelet transfusions.

Other options: 

Option A - Heparin should be discontinued if the patient has HIT. 

Option B - Lepirudin can be administered as it is an alternative anticoagulant. 

Option D - Rivaroxaban can be given as it is an alternative anticoagulant.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old female patient presents with complaints of weakness for the last 2 months. Additionally, she is facing difficulty rising from a chair, and combing her hair every morning. A physical exam reveals decreased strength in the shoulders and hip. Skin findings are as shown in the image. Which of the following is seen in this patient's condition?
  1. Perimyseal infiltrates
  2. Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles
  3. CD4+ cellular infiltrates
  4. Predominant distal muscle weakness
  5. Underlying malignancy
questions.solution:
In the given clinical vignette, this patient's symptoms along with the image findings showing heliotrope rash are highly suggestive of dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis involves CD 4+ cells, perimyseal infiltrates, and is associated with underlying malignancy. Hence, the correct findings are 1, 3, and 5.

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations. The pattern of muscle involvement helps distinguish a myopathy from a cerebral, spinal cord, neuronal or neuromuscular junction cause. It is commonly associated with an underlying malignancy.

Classic signs-

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids
  • V sign- Confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- Confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- Erythematous papules and plaques over extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints
  • Gottron's sign- Erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 
  • Mechanic’s hands- Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- Confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- Linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- Mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- Accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin.

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy and immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis is immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids being the first line. Methotrexate can be started as the second line if the patient presents with severe weakness, other organ system involvement, or those with risk of steroid complications like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women. Otherwise, second-line agents are only started in patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose. Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required. 

Note: Inclusion Body myositis is resistant to immunosuppressive medication
